Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <jl777c> @Takoy_Nahal you are working backwards from the conclusion you want to make and searching for datapoints that fit your theory. and in this case you conclude from "ZEC price dropped a lot more than XMR" to conclude that ASIC are evil. First off, miners can only influence the sell side and compared to the overall marketcap, daily mining is a small percentage. The buyers are the buyers, do you know that XMR and ZEC has the identical amount of buy support? 

what if XMR had 10x the buy support of ZEC? then ZEC outperformed relative to what it should have.

A most fatal flaw with your coin price "analysis" is that it ignores total coins. This is a large error. Right now XMR has 16 million coins with about 2200 coins per day mined. ZEC has over 7000 coins per day. So XMR has less than one third the new coins against 3x the supply. No wonder ZEC price dropped more during a bear market.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> so relatively speaking ZEC outperformed XMR by more than 2x. however, from this i wont conclude anything about anything as it is impossible to know the buy side. anyway, my position is that professional miners are miners and not married to any specific tech, so they will use CPU, GPU, FPGA, ASIC. since I know this is true, concluding any particular type of miner is somehow always selling 100% of what they mine, requires a lot of magic and rhetoric that is not based on logic

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> @jl777c Your theory would be correct if do not cite the example of an anonymous and popular Dash, which has 6 million coins in circulation, the extraction time of which is very similar to Zcash and Monero, but the number of coins in a block is 1.67! With a price of only 67 dollars. The coin is mined exclusively by ASIC miners. Then it turns out your theory is attracted to a specific answer and does not apply to many other similar coins. We mention the comparison of Zelcash and Hush. The time of block extraction is similar to Hush, despite the fact that there are 150 coins in the Zel block! and the number exceeds almost 10 times. I can give an infinite number of such examples. I do not claim that ASIC miners are the only reason for the fall in coin value, but I argue that this is the main reason. And such projects as Monero, Zcoin do protection against ASIC not because they are big fans of GPU miners, but because they understand that this is a larger community and less prone to such sales of coins. As I said earlier, I, as an investor and supporter of projects of the Komodo family, are very worried about such a deep drop in the cost of Hush, having sufficient experience in real-world communication with ASIC miners, reading various ASIC miners communities, and I learned this experience from ASIC miners. I don"t care how the ASIC / CPU / GPU coin will be mined. For me, it is important that the coin does not rapidly lose its value, if this value is affected by a large amount of sales from ASIC miners, then I am against the ASIC algorithm

About the depreciation of Zcash because of the big release, these are your words and Mr. Zooko, not mine

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> The lack of demand certainly pushes the price down, there are many factors that contribute to this. However, I am very annoyed that, under equal conditions, very similar coins, which have low demand, which lose value due to the bear market, in one case a drop of 3-5 times, in the other 10-20 times

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the only real answer is supply and demand, which are affected by dozens of things, most which cannot be accurately quantified. To make any "for sure" conclusions from such noisy and fuzzy data is not likely to be successful. It is like the BTC price drops $500 and then the news says "XYZ caused the price to drop $500". but that is totally bogus and just guesswork. I know some specific details about some such price movements and it had absolutely nothing to do with what the "experts" say

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the reality is that all crypto is tied to a large degree to BTC, so as BTC goes, the smaller coins go more. ie 10% BTC change -> 20% or even 50% change for a smaller coin

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> and most small coins have a very small number of large holders (who might be ASIC miners, or GPU miner from early days, or someone that bought on an exchange, or someone that inherited it when their spouse died). and any single one of these people can create a coin specific bear market on top of the BTC caused one

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> it is ok to have theories and you are welcome to have yours, just dont go pretending that there is anything close to 100% certainity

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <halo kitty rules> Absolutely, dead spouses are very important source. All HUSH HODLers with Chron's disease make sure your spouse has your private keys.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> With your statements, I agree and share your point of view about the impact of the value of BTC, a bear market and other factors. It is difficult to challenge.
100% in the world of cryptocurrency can not say anything. Everything is constantly changing, there are new factors and so on. But as I wrote about this above, I have experience in dealing with miners of ASIC and GPU, I read a lot of various forums of miners, listened to their opinions and thoughts. Is it possible to argue that there is no difference in the psychology of behavior of the two types of miners when one of the miners has a service life of 6 months and the other a few years? Can their behavior be similar? Definitely not. James (I hope you do not mind if I call you by name) you are a well-known person in the cryptocurrency world, you have a lot of experience and knowledge in the field of blockchain and cryptocurrency. I am very glad that there are people like you from whom we can learn a lot. But please answer me two questions:
The first question: Such projects as Monero, Zcoin, Bitcoin Gold, Ethereum and many others consistently adhere to the opinion of the protection of the algorithm from ASIC, change the algorithms and defend the point of view of security from ASIC. Question: Why do they do that? Why often declare commitment to GPU mining? Options:

1) They are wrong like me and do not understand the essence?
2) Are they populists and thus want to attract more people?
3) Are they GPU fans?
4) Another reason.

Second question: You know people like Alex Biryukov and Dmitry Khovratovich - the creators of the Equihash algorithm that Komodo runs on. According to Wikipedia: They created this algorithm specifically as protection against ASICs. Now these two people have created a new MTP algorithm, which, as I understand it, equalizes the capabilities of all types of miners, while remaining profitable for the GPU miners.
Q: Why do they do *message clipped*
